 Abstract In 1976 Argentine policymakers launched a major program to remove controls on prices, interest rates, and international transactions. Simultaneously, they attempted to rid the economy of inflation. By 1981 these reforms had been abandoned, and the economy had returned to hyperinflation. This paper documents the reactions of firms to the major changes in the environment between 1976 and 1981, and provides new evidence on why the reforms failed. The analysis is based upon the financial statements of 155 publicly traded industrial corporations. These statements are corrected for inflation and used to construct a time series of financial performance indicators for each firm. Values of these indicators are then compared over time for three major firm types: exportable goods producers, importable goods producers, and nontradeable goods producers. Perhaps the most fundamental lesson from the analysis is that extremely large subsidies were provided to the Argentine industrial sector by way of negative effective financial costs, These negative costs appeared first in the late 1970s because of the real peso appreciation, then again in 1981 because of the exchange insurance program. The amount of these subsidies for any firm was inversely related to its stock of monetary assets and directly related to its debt and to its exposure in foreign currency. So the relatively risky financial structures that emerged as the reform period progressed are probably partly traceable to the incentives created by these relationships. Unsurprisingly, large firms appear to have been the most heavily indebted in foreign currency. During the late 1970s firms substituted dollar debt for peso debt, keeping their overall leverage stable. But beginning in 1980, when earnings rates fell sharply, they steadily increased their reliance on debt finance. So increases in firms' financial riskiness may by this time have been partly due to distress borrowing. The earnings shortfall was caused by the temporary appearance of positive real peso interest rates and the disappearance of lucrative currency arbitrage possibilities. For tradeable goods producers this shortfall was made worse by major reductions in price-cost margins -- probably reflecting the government's policy of forcing down inflation by systematically slowing the devaluation rate. Average earnings rates (after correcting for inflation) were restored by the exchange insurance program in 1981, but the financial environment was by then much more volatile than during the late 1970s. Not only were leverages higher and liquidity levels much lower, but gross operating earnings were reduced and highly variable across firms. Both importable and nontradeable goods producers suffered a major reduction in capacity utilization, and although price-cost margins improved for tradeables with several maxi-devaluations, bankruptcies multiplied. The industrial sector did not rid itself of dollar debt as the 1981 devaluations became certain. Given that the exchange insurance program was immediately instituted, this proved to have been a shrewd policy. But it also contributed to the severe balance of payments crisis from which the Argentine government has yet to escape.

 I. BACKGROUND A. Introduction Upon taking office in 1976, a new team of Argentine policymakers set out to dismantle government controls on prices, interest rates, international trade, and capital flows. Liberalization proceeded rapidly for interest rates and capital flows, but the persistence of hyperinflation frustrated the team's attempt to create an efficient free-market economy. So, after contractionary monetary policies and temporarily reimposed wage and price controls proved unsuccessful, the policymakers decided in 1978 to retard the pace of currency devaluation according to a preannounced schedule. It was hoped that this new exchange rate regime, called the "tablita," would break inflationary expectations and, by pulling down domestic interest rates, maintain aggregate demand. The combined effects of these liberalization and stabilization policies did not coincide with intentions. Rather than force inflation down for all sectors, the tablita caused the ratio of tradable to nontradeable good prices to fall by two-thirds between 1977 and 1981. Moreover, despite the removal of most restrictions on international capital movements, the real cost of peso borrowing typically exceeded that of dollar borrowing by 40 percent to 100 percent a year. Nor was inflation ever conquered. Instead, foreign currency reserves at the Central Bank became so depleted that by 1981 major devaluations were inevitable. These devaluations effectively ended the attempt at liberalization -- and ushered in interest controls, subsidized foreign exchange insurance for firms with dollar indebtedness, and other capital market interventions.

Solvency Problems A crisis of solvency occurs when the value of assets falls to within a narrow margin of total debt obligations. Like liquidity crises, the crises of solvency often occur after a prolonged period of negative real earnings rates. But these can also be suddenly brought on by adverse revaluation effects. When a firm's assets no longer exceed its debts, it is technically insolvent and becomes the property of its creditors. Its assets are sold and the proceeds are divided among creditors in accord with the provisions of the contracts they held. doc.repnme: How the financial statements of Argentine firms reflected stabilization and reform attempts during 1976-81
doc.abstracts: In 1976 Argentine policymakers launched a major program to remove controls on prices, interest rates, and international transactions. Simultaneously, they attempted to rid the economy of inflation. By 1981 these reforms had been abandoned, and the economy had returned to hyperinflation. This paper documents the reactions of firms to the major changes in the environment between 1976 and 1981, and provides new evidence on why the reforms failed. The analysis is based upon the financial statements of 155 publicly traded industrial corporations. These statements are corrected for inflation and used to construct a time series of financial performance indicators for each firm. Values of these indicators are then compared over time for three major firm types: exportable goods producers, importable goods producers, and nontradeable good producers.
